questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?

options.option_text: JavaScript is a low level programming language.
The “const” keyword can be used to declare objects with block level scope.
Int, char are some primitive data types in the JavaScript language.
The JavaScript language supports both the first order and higher orderfunctions.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: A web application must implement token based authentication to make theapplication secure.
The JAMStack approach separates out the frontend from the backend, andthey both can be updated/modified independently without affecting the other.
It is recommended to avoid the usage of verbs in the API data URLs.
The idea behind bringing an API is to implement caching.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?

options.option_text: A Celery system can only use Redis as the message broker.
A Celery system may consist of a number of batch jobs.
A Celery system needs worker(s) to execute tasks.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?

options.option_text: The term “polling” generally refers to short polling.
Webhooks are used for 1 way communication, unlike web sockets.
In polling, the connection to the server is kept open, until the data is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?

options.option_text: Cookies are stored on the server.
Cookies are stored on the browser.
Browser sends the cookies to the origin server automatically in general.
Client has to include cookies manually with the request, in general.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?

options.option_text: It is a protocol to allow access to resources, hosted on a different server, onbehalf of a user.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?

options.option_text: Closure is the state of the outer function.
Closure is the state of a variable.
Closure is a function along with its lexical environment or surrounding state.
Closures are created every time a function is created in JavaScript.

options.option_text: The flask framework enforces CSRF protection by default.
The CORS mechanism allows a developer to secure a web application fromexternal origins.
The CORS headers are generally prefixed with the value “Access-Control-Allow”.
An anti CSRF token must be sent with the request, if CSRF protection isenabled.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: The server sent events is a mechanism for a server to push events, and it mustrequire service workers on the client to function properly.
In general, a webhook is meant to pull message(s) from an application.
The usage of a message broker over “point-to-point” communication makesthe application scalable.
There is no difference between webhooks and short polling.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)

options.option_text: The approach 1 will wait for a user input before dispatching the task to thecelery system.
The approach 2 will dispatch the task to the celery system after waiting for 10seconds, and start the execution, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 2 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, butstart the execution after waiting for 10 seconds, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 1 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, andstart the execution, assuming a worker is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?

options.option_text: In general, an application should have separate Vuex stores for all thecomponents.
A path defined in the routes array in Vue router can consist of a number ofchildren paths.
The wildcard (*) should be put at the top of the routes array in the Vue router,so that it matches with all the paths, which are not implemented.
A Vuex store must be used with all Vue applications.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding fetch API?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding fetch API?

options.option_text: The credentials property of the Request interface allows the user agent tosend or receive cookies in cross-origin requests.
The value “omit” of “credentials” will force the browser not to send cookies withthe request.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialseven in cross-origin requests.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialsonly for same origin requests.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?

options.option_text: The local storage is a browser based persistent storage.
Cookies are preferred over session or local storage, when the data needs to besent with every request.
The cookies can be set from the server as well as using javascript on the client.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts** ### **1. JavaScript Fundamentals** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Primitive Data Types**: `number`, `string`, `boolean`, `null`, `undefined`, `symbol`, `BigInt` (No `int`/`char` in JS). - **`const` vs `let`**: - `const`: Block-scoped, cannot be reassigned (but objects/arrays can be mutated). - `let`: Block-scoped, can be reassigned. - **First-Order vs Higher-Order Functions**: - **First-Order**: Treated as variables (passed as args, returned from functions). - **Higher-Order**: Accepts/returns functions (e.g., `map`, `filter`). - **Closures**: - A function + its lexical environment (surrounding state). - Created every time a function is defined. - **Promises & Async/Await**: - `.then()`: Handles resolved promises. - `.catch()`: Handles rejections. - `.finally()`: Executes regardless of resolution/rejection. - `async/await`: Syntactic sugar for promises. - **Arrow Functions vs Regular Functions**: - Arrow functions inherit `this` from the parent scope. - Regular functions have their own `this` (dynamic binding). #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** ```javascript // Closure Example function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; } const closure = outer(); // x is preserved in closure. // Promise Example new Promise((resolve, reject) => { if (success) resolve("Done"); else reject("Error"); }) .then(d => console.log(d)) .catch(e => console.log(e)); // Async/Await Example async function fetchData() { const data = await someAsyncTask(); console.log(data); } ``` --- ### **2. Modern Web Development** #### **Key Concepts:** - **JAMStack**: - **J**avaScript, **A**PIs, **M**arkup. - Decouples frontend (static) from backend (dynamic APIs). - **REST API Design**: - Avoid verbs in URLs (use nouns, e.g., `/users` instead of `/getUsers`). - **Caching**: Not the primary purpose of APIs (but can be implemented via headers). - **Authentication/Authorization**: - **OAuth**: Authorization protocol (delegated access to resources). - **Tokens**: JWT/OAuth tokens for stateless auth. - **CSRF Protection**: Anti-CSRF tokens in forms (not enforced by default in Flask). - **CORS**: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (headers like `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`). - **Cookies vs Local Storage vs Session Storage**: | Feature | Cookies | Local Storage | Session Storage | |------------------|-----------------------|---------------------|---------------------| | **Persistence** | Configurable (expire) | Persistent | Session-only | | **Storage Limit**| ~4KB | ~5MB | ~5MB | | **Access** | Sent with every HTTP request | Client-side only | Client-side only | | **Use Case** | Auth tokens, tracking | Offline data | Temporary data | #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** ```javascript // CORS Header Example (Server-Side) response.setHeader("Access-Control-Allow-Origin", "*"); // CSRF Token Example (Flask)
// Local Storage Example localStorage.setItem("key", "value"); const data = localStorage.getItem("key"); ``` --- ### **3. Vue.js** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Directives**: - `v-model`: Two-way data binding. - `v-for`: Render lists. - `v-if`/`v-show`: Conditional rendering. - `v-bind`: Dynamic attributes (e.g., `:class`). - `v-on`: Event handling (e.g., `@click`). - **Components**: - Reusable Vue instances with their own templates, data, and methods. - **Props**: Pass data from parent to child. - **Slots**: Inject content into components. - **Computed Properties vs Methods**: - **Computed**: Cached, reactive (use for derived data). - **Methods**: Re-run on every render (use for event handlers). - **Vue Router**: - Dynamic routing with `vue-router`. - `router-view`: Renders matched components. - `router-link`: Navigation links. - **Nested Routes**: Children routes under a parent. - **Vuex (State Management)**: - **State**: Single source of truth. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state updates. - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - **Getters**: Computed properties for state. - **Class/Style Binding**: - `:class="{ active: isActive }"` (object syntax). - `:class="[classA, classB]"` (array syntax). - **Lifecycle Hooks**: - `created`, `mounted`, `updated`, `destroyed`. #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** ```javascript // Vue Component Example Vue.component('my-component', { props: ['message'], template: `
{{ message }}
` }); // Vuex Store Example const store = new Vuex.Store({ state: { count: 0 }, mutations: { increment(state) { state.count++; } }, actions: { incrementAsync({ commit }) { setTimeout(() => commit('increment'), 1000); } } }); // Vue Router Example const router = new VueRouter({ routes: [ { path: '/', component: Home }, { path: '/about', component: About } ] }); ``` --- ### **4. Asynchronous Communication** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Polling vs Webhooks vs WebSockets**: | Method | Description | Direction | Connection | |--------------|--------------------------------------|-----------------|------------------| | **Polling** | Client repeatedly asks server. | Client → Server | Short-lived | | **Webhooks** | Server pushes to client via HTTP. | Server → Client | Stateless | | **WebSockets** | Full-duplex, persistent connection. | Bi-directional | Long-lived | - **Server-Sent Events (SSE)**: - Server pushes events to client over HTTP (no service workers required). - **Message Brokers (Celery + Redis)**: - **Celery**: Distributed task queue. - **Redis**: In-memory data store (can act as a message broker). - **Tasks**: - `task.delay()`: Immediate execution. - `task.apply_async(countdown=10)`: Delayed execution. #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** ```javascript // Webhook Example (Server-Side) app.post('/webhook', (req, res) => { console.log("Received:", req.body); res.status(200).end(); }); // Celery Task Example (Python) @celery.task def send_email(): print("Sending email...") # Delayed execution send_email.apply_async(countdown=10) ``` --- ### **5. Fetch API & HTTP** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Credentials in Fetch**: - `credentials: 'include'`: Send cookies in cross-origin requests. - `credentials: 'omit'`: Exclude cookies. - `credentials: 'same-origin'`: Default (send cookies for same origin). - **Request Methods**: - `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`, `PATCH`. - **Headers**: - `Content-Type`: `application/json`, `multipart/form-data`. - `Authorization`: `Bearer `. #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** ```javascript // Fetch API Example fetch('https://api.example.com/data', { method: 'POST', credentials: 'include', // Send cookies headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }, body: JSON.stringify({ key: 'value' }) }) .then(response => response.json()) .then(data => console.log(data)); ``` --- ### **6. Security** #### **Key Concepts:** - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - Restricts cross-origin requests unless explicitly allowed. - Headers: `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`, `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`. - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)**: - Attacker tricks user into submitting a malicious request. - Mitigation: Anti-CSRF tokens in forms. - **OAuth 2.0**: - **Authorization** (not authentication). - Roles: Resource Owner, Client, Authorization Server, Resource Server. - **JWT (JSON Web Tokens)**: - Stateless auth tokens (header.payload.signature). --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **1. JavaScript Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[JavaScript] --> B[Primitive Types] A --> C[Variables] C --> C1[const] C --> C2[let] A --> D[Functions] D --> D1[First-Order] D --> D2[Higher-Order] A --> E[Closures] E --> E1[Lexical Environment] A --> F[Asynchronous] F --> F1[Promises] F --> F2[Async/Await] F --> F3[Event Loop] ``` ### **2. Vue.js Ecosystem** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vue.js] --> B[Directives] B --> B1[v-model] B --> B2[v-for] B --> B3[v-if/v-show] A --> C[Components] C --> C1[Props] C --> C2[Slots] A --> D[State Management] D --> D1[Vuex] D1 --> D1a[State] D1 --> D1b[Mutations] D1 --> D1c[Actions] D1 --> D1d[Getters] A --> E[Routing] E --> E1[vue-router] E1 --> E1a[Dynamic Routes] E1 --> E1b[Nested Routes] ``` ### **3. Web Communication Methods** ```mermaid graph TD A[Client-Server Communication] --> B[Polling] A --> C[Webhooks] A --> D[WebSockets] A --> E[Server-Sent Events] B --> B1[Short Polling] B --> B2[Long Polling] C --> C1[HTTP-Based] C --> C2[One-Way] D --> D1[Full-Duplex] D --> D2[Persistent Connection] E --> E1[Server Push] E --> E2[HTTP] ``` ### **4. Authentication & Security** ```mermaid graph TD A[Security] --> B[Authentication] B --> B1[OAuth 2.0] B --> B2[JWT] A --> C[Authorization] C --> C1[OAuth Scopes] A --> D[CORS] D --> D1[Access-Control-Allow-Origin] A --> E[CSRF] E --> E1[Anti-CSRF Tokens] A --> F[Cookies] F --> F1[HttpOnly] F --> F2[Secure] F --> F3[SameSite] ``` ### **5. Asynchronous Task Queues (Celery + Redis)** ```mermaid graph TD A[Celery] --> B[Task Queue] A --> C[Workers] A --> D[Broker] D --> D1[Redis] D --> D2[RabbitMQ] A --> E[Task Execution] E --> E1[delay] E --> E2[apply_async] ```
